text: language notes topic 10 getting paid how
many ways can you ask a person how much
money he or she makes you could ask how
much do you make how much do you earn or
what do you earn what do you get paid
what do you charge all of these
questions are grammatically correct but
you need to be very careful in the u.s.
how much money a person earns is
generally considered a private matter
even among very close friends we don't
usually ask directly how much do you
make perhaps only young people just
starting to work would speak so freely
about what they get paid for example
when I first started babysitting I got
two to three dollars an hour today
babysitters in my area earn 10 sometimes
15 dollars an hour which is close to
what I got paid when I first started
teaching how much do I earn now you're
not supposed to ask if someone asks you
how much do you make you could give a
vague answer you could say enough or you
could say maybe not as much as I'd like
to so perhaps it's more common to hear
these questions about other people not
how much do you make but how much does a
professional athlete make not how much
do you earn but how much does a doctor
earn how much does a lawyer get paid in
his or her first year after law school
now this last question is a litte
different what do you charge is
referring to a fee doctors lawyers
consultants agents charge a fee and it
is appropriate to ask what these people
charge before you receive their services
people who work either have a salary or
earn wages what's the difference in the
u.s. when we stay salary we're mostly
referring to an annual salary this is
how much a person earns within a year a
salary is common for a full-time job
meaning 40 hours a week a salary is also
common for professional jobs in contrast
when we speak of wages we're talking
about getting paid on a daily basis a
weekly basis or an hourly basis we can
talk about hourly wages
you also hear hourly rate what's your
hourly rate meaning how much do you get
paid per hour we can talk about high
wages low wages good wages bad wages or
poor wages those are common phrases with
the word wages we also in the u.s. talk
about a minimum wage that's the least
amount of money a person can get paid
for a job the least amount per hour
there is a federal minimum wage meaning
a wage for the whole country but each
state could also set a minimum wage
that's slightly higher currently the
minimum wage in the u.s. is 7 to 8
dollars an hour many of us would love to
talk about earning a six-figure salary
what's that in other words a salary with
six figures a hundred thousand dollars
or more we use K to refer two thousand
so a six-figure salary has six figures
wouldn't that be
all right some people have what's called
a base salary that's what they earn
per year but then there's more that they
could earn perhaps they can earn a bonus
extra money at the end of the year
perhaps they work on Commission or
partly on Commission that means if they
make a sale they get part of that profit
so base salary could increase with a
bonus or with Commission also they might
get paid overtime the word overtime
refers to the hours a person works
beyond the 40-hour workweek here's a
truth not everyone in the same position
earns the same amount of money that's
because there is a salary range for a
certain position companies can pay
between this amount and another amount
of money an entry-level position for
example might pay between thirty five
and forty five thousand dollars a year
if you want to earn more you can move up
the pay scale you can move up the pay
scale with more education more training
more experience after you receive more
education more training more experience
then you can seek a pay increase
you can request a raise
in the US we have a progressive tax
system if you earn more money you pay
more taxes when we talk about someone's
earnings there are two figures we can
talk about gross earnings or gross
income same thing or we can talk about
look excuse me
net earnings or net income do you know
these words gross earnings or gross
income is what a person earns before
taxes before federal taxes state taxes
Social Security and other deductions
like health insurance life insurance
retirement plans net earnings net income
is what you're left with after taxes
after all the deductions so a person's
annual salary is not actually what they
take home at the very end what they have
at the very end after taxes after
deductions is a net income net earnings
the word income can be used not just for
an individual but a household people who
live in the same home a family what is
the household income so if there are two
people working there are two incomes two
sources of income and we can have
high-income and low-income families
high-income and low-income households
how many ways can a person get paid they
could get paid by check in which case we
call it a paycheck there's an expression
in English called living from paycheck
to paycheck if you live from paycheck to
paycheck you don't have much extra money
you need each paycheck to pay all of
your bills to pay for all of your
expenses not many people receive
paychecks today I'd say a good number of
people have a direct deposit our
earnings go directly to our bank
accounts for some jobs like babysitting
perhaps or cutting the grass for a
neighbor you'll get paid in cash if
you're getting paid cash and you pay
your taxes everything's legal if you're
getting cashed and you do not report
these earnings to the government you are
getting paid under the table which is
not legal that's all for now I hope you
found it interesting to talk about
getting paid and I hope you learned some
useful vocabulary some new words and
expressions thanks for watching and
happy studies
please visit my website today at WWE
English with Jennifer calm you'll find
study tips interactive exercises
vocabulary videos and more
